Superstar Ability - You may drop 3 coins to use the Super Star ability of any other character on the board.
Power-Up Ability - (Pow) All other players drop 1 coins. You may advance to the space directly behind the next player on the board. Follow the rule for that space.
Families: Video Game Theme: Super Mario Bros.

Name: War
Description:
All that exists of this game is the board.  It is not known whether there was a spinner or die/dice were used to move the players along. Number of players is unknown.

The game looks to be about the Spanish American War (the enemy flags are Red and Yellow, similar to the Spanish Flag of the time). The theater could reflect the battle for Cuba. Possibly reflecting the Naval battle of Santiago Bay in the lower center and San Juan Hill as the final point the players are trying to attain.

Name: The Game of Air-Sea Rescue
Description:
This game was published with a license from the RAF benevolent fund and was published during WWII (exact date is unknown). The manual describes some aids used to facilitate pilot rescue.

Players roll a die and move a downed pilot up a track. Once the pilot reaches a certain point on the track a spotter plane launches from the other end of the track. The player may only move the pilot or the spotter plane.  Once they meet at a specified point on the board, then a rescue ship is launched from the end of the track and must go meet the pilot at which point they move to the end of the board and rescue.

Name: Arcane Armies
Description:
A common deck card game for 2-4+ players with a fantasy army-building conquest theme.
 Players share a common deck. There are 2 basic card types: Units and Spells. 
Units are further divided into Individuals and Groups. All cards have a strength value between 0 and 10 and a special ability that is activated and resolved as soon as the card is played.

The deck is shuffled and placed face down in the centre of the table. The top card is flipped over to be the start of the discard pile. The first player to go is dealt 2 cards. 
The second player to go is dealt 3 cards. The third player to go is dealt 4 cards and so on.

Players then take turns with each turn being divided into 4 phases:


     Conquest Phase
         You win if, at the beginning of your turn, your cards in play have a combined strength of 40 or more.  
    
     Scour Phase
         Draw 1 card from the deck and put it in your hand.  
    
     Deploy Phase
         Play 1 card from your hand face up to the table. Immediately resolve the card’s special ability. If the card has a strength of zero (most spells) it is immediately discarded. Otherwise it stays in play as part of your army, its strength contributing to your army’s total strength. You may play a second card if the strength of both cards played is 10 or less. 
    
     Last Phase
         You may unflip a card in play by discarding a card from your hand.  Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards. 
    


A player wins if, at the beginning of your turn, your cards in play have a combined strength of 40 or more.

Name: Wealth Manager
Description:
A card game for 2-4+ players in which players try to increase their net worth and earning potential.

Players share 2 common decks. Players begin with the starting deck and then move onto the expert deck. There are 9 Card types: Acumen, Real Estate, Business Investment, Debt Management, Personal Expenses, Business Expenses, Stock Portfolio, Collectible Items and Windfall.

Each player starts the game with: 
Job Income: 8K per month 
Total Expenses: 6K per month 
Savings: 15K 
Stock Market Portfolio: 15K
Assets: Home = 300K and Cars = 30K
Retirement Funds = 200K
Liabilities: Mortgage = 250K and Cars = 20K

Players take turns (representing 1 month) with each turn comprising 5 phases:

1.    Payday
-     Earn money from all of your income streams including job, businesses, and rentals.

2.    Expenses
-     Pay for all your expenses. This includes mortgage payments, car payments, living expenses, loan payments, and real estate overhead.

3.   Opportunity
-    Draw 1 card from the current deck. The card drawn will present either an opportunity you may take, or an extra expense you must take depending on the card.

4.   Market
-    This phase represents volatility in the markets. Players roll on the asset adjustment table once for each of their assets to see if value or income is affected.

5.   End 
-    Discard all cards. Calculate your Net Worth.

The game ends when players have gone through both decks. The player with the highest net worth is the winner. If tied, the player with the highest monthly income is the winner. If still tied, the player with the most liquid cash wins.

Name: Mad Max
Description:
A card game for 2-4+ players based on the Mad Max series of movies.

Players share a common deck comprising 7 different card types (with 10 different cards in each suit): Max, Leadership, Foe, Vehicle, Aid, Survivor and Location.

Each player is dealt 7 cards and then take turns, with each turn comprising 3 phases:

Drive Phase
-   Fill your hand to 8 cards.

Fight Phase 
-   Discard 1 card to produces an effect dependant on the type of card:
•   Max = Look at an opponent’s hand
•   Leadership = Look at next 7 cards in deck
•   Foe = Opponent must discard 1 random card
•   Vehicle = Search discard for 1 card
•   Aid = Steal 1 random card from an opponent’s hand
•   Survivor = Draw 2 cards
•   Location = Draw 3 cards and discard 2 cards

Survive Phase
-   Discard down to 7 cards. 
-   If you have 1 card of each type this is a meld and can be played (discarded)

The first player to make 3 melds is the winner.

Name: 7 ühe hoobiga
Description:
There are 52 different animals and information about these animals on the cards and You can play 7 different variants more and less similar to Top Trumps.

Draw the top card from Your deck, ask either average lifespan, weight and offspring and who has the biggest number in this category take the trump.

Name: Battleship Bismarck
Description:
A solitaire (or two players as well) game about naval-air battles of the II World World. Contains various battles, since 1939 (attack on the minelayer ORP Gryf) till 1942 (attack on the aircraft carrier Hiryu). Some scenarios can be played together in the campaign mode (like three Bismarck scenarios), while the others are stand alone ones.

Game uses tables and counters to show the effeciency of the attacks of the aircrafts or artillery duels between ships. Rules are short and easy, so the game can be played about 15 minutes after opening the box.

Name: Poland 1920
Description:
When the World War I ended, a new war began in the Eastern Europe.Bolshevik Russia marched west to bring to bring the communist revolution to all Europe. Poland, which had just gained independence after 123 years of captivity, was its first target.

Game focuses on the Polish-Bolshevik war of the 1920 and allows players to recreate the crucial moments of this conflict in the operational, division scale play.

Name: Paranoia: Troubleshooters
Description:
A card game based on the Paranoia RPG.

You live underground in a giant complex controlled by a paranoid computer. This complex is called Alpha Complex. The Computer is your friend. Traitors are executed. Good Citizens help root out Traitors. Mutants are traitors. Secret Society members are traitors. You are a Mutant and a Secret Society Member. You know very little because of your (Red) low security clearance. You have been assigned to a team of Troubleshooters. Troubleshooters shoot trouble. Stay Alert! Trust No One! Keep your Laser Handy!

Each player has a family of 6 clones. Every time your clone is killed, one of your remaining clones takes his place. When all six have been killed you lose and are out of the game. Players try to survive while killing off their opponent’s clones.

There are 2 decks: The Mission Deck and The Paranoia Deck.  Cards are of 4 types: Combat, Comprehension, Communication and Treason.

Each turn has 4 Phases:

1.  Requisition Phase
-   Each player fills their hand to 5 cards from the Paranoia Deck.

2.  Mission Phase
-   Flip over the top card of the Mission Deck. This describes an encounter all players must face. The encounter will be one of three types: Combat, Comprehension, or Communication. Each player must play (discard) one Paranoia card of a matching type to survive. If a player cannot play a matching card his Clone is killed.

3.  Action Phase
-   The current player may initiate one or more actions. Actions require the expenditure of Paranoia cards. He may continue doing this until he has no cards left in his hand.  The Actions include: 
•   Situational Awareness: Discard 2 Comprehension cards to draw 3 Paranoia cards and put them in your hand. 
•   Accusations: Play one or more Treason cards onto an opponent. The opponent may play Communication cards to discard Treason cards on a one to one basis.  If a player has 3 or more Treason cards and no way to discard them, that clone is immediately terminated by the computer. 
•   Shoot the Traitor: The player picks a target opposing player who has at least 
one Treason card. Both play combat cards from their hands. The player who plays more combat cards kills the opposing player. If both play an equal number of cards then roll 1D6: The higher roll wins. If still tied, both are killed. 
•   Special Actions: Some cards allow for special actions when played. These special actions (SA) are described on the individual cards. 
-    All played cards from Action Phase are discarded.

4.  Debriefing Phase
-   Max hand size is 5 cards.  Discard any excess cards.

The aim of the game is to kill off all your opponents’ clones and be the last one alive.

Name: Stupid Users: BETA
Description:
Description from the designers:

Stupid Users: BETA is a one of a kind, IT vs Zombies, Card Game about building up an army and stealing or looting anything to win. You read that right, IT vs Zombies. This isn't your typical card game. Get ready for a fast paced, trash talking, turn on a dime, army building card game. It starts like this; choose your IT Champion, cards are dealt, you're fighting against the other players, and the evil Der Magicker a diabolical hacker. You see Der Magicker is building his army of zombies to take over the world and more importantly beat you and the other players. Champions must gather or steal weapons, troops, and strategically play cards to beat Der Magicker and the other players. There are many ways to gather your army, draw a card, attack another player, kill a higher powered zombie, etc. Pay close attention because one card will change the game entirely or can be a win card with the correct gameplay. No sleeping allowed! Let the game begin, if you dare......

Name: The Spanish Main
Description: Vintage spin and move game. Players are traveling across the board  so many steps as shown on spin indicator. The first player, who occupies Merchantman square wins the game.

Name: Hot Blood, Cold Steel: The Battle of Chawinda, September 15-16, 1965
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Hot Blood, Cold Steel is a war game simulation of the climactic battle fought near Chawinda, India. On September 1st, 1965 Pakistani forces launched Operation Grand Slam, an offensive intended to secure approaches to Jammu and Kashmir provinces from India.

Outnumbered Indian frontier forces fought desperate holding actions that successfully held the Pakistanis to limited gains that brought them to the outskirts of their objective, the town of Phillora. On September 15th Indian forces launched their counter-attack,

Operation Riddle, that sought to throw back the Pakistanis and take back the crucial crossroads town of Chawinda. What ensued was the largest tank battle of the post-WWII era to that date, one that would only be eclipsed by the 1973 Yom Kippur War.

Each copy of Hot Blood, Cold Steel is composed of the following:

Two 11 by 17 inch hex map sheets
One sheet of 180 single-sided, un-mounted counters (mounted counters can be had for an additional $5.00).
One Players' aid sheet
7 pages of rules

The game is designed by Paul Rohrbaugh with graphics by Ilya Kudriashov. Hot Blood, Cold Steel uses the Blood and Steel design. Players draw formation chits to activate their formations and units, and play is very interactive. A complete game takes about 2 to 3 hours to complete. Although designed for two players, Hot Blood, Cold Steel is well suited to solitaire play.

Name: Wir spielen Baustelle
Description:
Ui, on this site is something going on. Who helps to find the right building materials? 
The children learn how to build a house step by step and to find out what kind of work and materials are needed. The adults support the children by declaring and naming construction work, building materials and vehicles after the six building lots.
When navigating the road network between construction sites, the kids also train their fine motor skills. Then the children let the colorful trucks ride along the streets. With the help of the small trucks, the children now transport the wrongly supplied building material to the right construction sites. 
Depending on the development stage of the children, only three and later all construction sites are to be supplied. In assigning and discovering the colorful construction site, the everyday knowledge and logical thinking of the little ones is stimulated playfully. For older children, game variations with first rules are possible and the color cubes are used.

Name: Tärningslotto
Description:
Despite its name ("die lotto") this children's game may be considered more like a distant relative of Go Fish than regular Lotto.

Each player is a given a picture board with spaces for tiles, and the corresponding tiles are mixed and placed face down, displaying only a number from 1-6. Players roll the die and try to collect their own tiles by picking them first from the shared pool, and when this is exhausted, from tiles picked up by other players. The winner is the first player to obtain all their tiles and complete the picture on their board. The rules as printed actually contains several incongruities and ambiguities leaving important aspects up to extrapolation or guesswork.

There is no date of publication, but the 70s is a decent guess.

Name: Swords
Description:
Swords is a fast-paced simultaneous action card game for 2-5 players that feels like a multi-person sword fight!  It's quick, fun, intense, strategic, and not too difficult to learn.  Players play their cards at the same time either on themselves or on an opponent and each card has a different effect depending on where it's played!

Swords is an exciting game of quick decisions and sudden changes in fortune, just like a real sword fight!  You and your opponents make your decisions in secret and execute them at the same time, strategies adapt by the second, and every hand is a surprise!  You can win by playing aggressively, always attacking and making opponents draw cards, or you can hope that the others will be so busy fighting each other that they won't notice your quickly diminishing hand as you Yield and discard an extra card.  Often a person you were just attacking might suddenly become an ally when you realize, almost too late, that someone else is about to win and you need to team up to take them down!  There are many different strategies, some readily apparent and others more sneaky, and reading your opponents is just as important as making the right choice at the right time!

Here's a quick summary of how to play!

Everyone starts with seven cards. Each round, players each choose a card in secret and then play their cards at the same time.  The goal of the game is to run out of cards first.

There are four types of cards: Attack, Defend, Yield, and Riposte.

You can play any card on yourself or an opponent and each card does a different thing depending on where it is played!

Attack when played on an opponent makes them draw 2 cards.  If you play it on yourself you lay a trap for any player who plays a card on you, making them draw 4 cards.  But look out, it's risky!  Anything that's played on you still hits you, and if no one plays anything on you the trap backfires and you have to draw 2 yourself!

Defend when played on yourself does what you might expect, it defends you!  When you play it on someone else, it acts as a sort of guard break, negating cards they've played on themselves... just watch out for that Attack trap, Defend is defenseless against that!

Yield lets you sneak an extra card into the discard pile when you play it on yourself.  When you play it on an opponent, however, instead of putting that extra card in the discard you give it to them!  Like some kind of card vampire!

Riposte is like a counter attack when you play it on yourself, it bounces Attacks, Yields, and Ripostes back at the person who played them on you.  When you play Riposte on someone else it immobilizes them for the next turn, leaving them wide open!  Careful though, if more than half of the people playing lay down Riposte on the same turn it causes a Clash and every single person has to draw 2 cards!

The main game is played with 3-5 players but there is also a fun and sneaky 2 player variant that shakes things up with a hidden Dagger mechanic!

A battle usually lasts around 5 to 10 minutes!  You can play single battles or play a war where battles award 1 point for a tie or 2 points for winning alone, and the first player to 6 points wins the war!

—description from the designer

Name: Gloup!
Description:
A fun game which enhances memory and logic skills. Knowing that goats eat cabbages, that wolves eat goats and that all of them fear dogs, how will you cross a river with wolves, goats, dogs and cabbages without losing too many of them? Rules are simple, the goal is to earn as many points as possible by saving "passengers" (animals or vegetables).

Each player begins the game with a hand of 4 cards taken from his own Passenger deck. Each turn, the active player reveals the top card from a common Placement deck, perform the appropriate action by playing a card from her hand, then discards it. She may also optionally play an Action card from her hand if she has any left.

Passenger cards are cards picturing animals (Wolf, Goat or Shepperd dog) or vegetables (Cannage), while Action cards have an effect on all players.

Players must fill boats with 3 passengers before they leave for the Island where the passangers will disenbark. Players must keep in mind that when disembarking, Goats will eat Cabbages and Wolves will eat Goats, unless there's a Shepperd dog in the boat to check on everyone. Players get points for all Passengers getting safely to the Isaland.

The game ends when a players plays the last Passenger card from his hand, which triggers the last turn. Players add-up all their points and the one with the most points wins!

Name: Tact
Description:
Description from the designer:

Tact is the quick game of pure negotiation.

In this 10-minute alternative to Diplomacy (One Night Ultimate Diplomacy, perhaps), players receive one colour card each and have one minute to talk to other players and submit their order cards detailing which player they will attack and with whom (if anyone) they will ally. When it comes time to submit orders, however, those alliances may count for nothing. Points are earned for successfully attacking and for not being attacked and are tallied to crown the winner.

Wheel, deal, backstab and betray. Make friends, make enemies. A winning strategy just takes a little Tact.

Name: Broadsword: A Game of Legendary Heroes and Epic Adventure
Description:
Description from the publisher:

A high fantasy tactical adventure game that seamlessly marries elements from classic boardgames with elements from tabletop roleplaying games to result in something novel — much more than a simple boardgame; not quite a full RPG.

One player is the GM. The rest of the players choose a combination of race and class for their Hero. Certain spellcasting classes also get a deck of spell cards, unique to that class. The players team up to defeat the evil monsters of the Abyss, achieve the Quest goal, and find the exit to the map (typically leading to the start of the next Quest).

On each turn, a Hero may take an Action then move, or move then take an Action. An "Action" is one of nine possibilities: Attack, Cast a Spell, Search for Treasure, Search for Secret Doors, Search for Traps, Disarm a Trap, Use an Active Skill, Use a Special Action, Switch Items.

Movement around the map each turn takes 1d6+4 squares. Attacking, defending, and some other actions are performed with pictographic Combat Dice.

The Heroes lose the Quest if they fail to achieve the Quest objective, or if all Heroes are killed before they find the exit to the map.

Name: Munchkin Lite
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Go down in the dungeon. Kill everything you meet. Backstab your friends and steal their stuff. Grab the treasure and run.

Munchkin Lite has all the same dungeon-crawling, pun-making, backstabbing madness of original Munchkin, but with 115 cards, it's the perfect size for three to four players. Take it anywhere, and play it in an hour!

Name: Munchkin Shakespeare: Drama Dice
Description: Munchkin Shakespeare Drama Dice features six dice colored to match the components of Munchkin Shakespeare, along with four new cards for that game.

Name: Lobotomy: Faceless Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Faceless monster (Slender Man), and includes the miniature and rules.

The Faceless Expansion is a Kickstarter exclusive, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle I".

Name: Lobotomy: Guardian Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Faceless monster (originally called Silent Angels), and includes four miniatures and rules.

The Guardian Expansion is a Kickstarter exclusive, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle I".

Name: Lobotomy: Possessed Nuns Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Possessed Nuns monster type, and includes four miniatures and rules.

The Possessed Nuns Expansion is a Kickstarter exclusive, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle I".

Name: Lobotomy: Slytherio Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Slytherio monster, and includes a miniature and rules.

The Slytherio Expansion was initially available through the Kickstarter, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle II" and the "Monster Bundle III".

Slytherio was not a Kickstarter Exclusive.

Name: Lobotomy: Three Little Pigs Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Three Little Pigs monsters, and includes three miniatures and rules.

The Three Little Pigs expansion was initially available through the Kickstarter, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle II" and the "Monster Bundle III".

The Three Little Pigs expansion was not a Kickstarter Exclusive.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Three Little Pigs

Name: Lobotomy: Executioner Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Executioner monster, and includes a miniature and rules.

The Executioner Expansion was initially available through the Kickstarter, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle II" and the "Monster Bundle III".

The Executioner Expansion was not a Kickstarter Exclusive.

Name: Lobotomy: Big Bad Wolf Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the Big Bad Wolf monster, and includes a miniature and rules.

The Big Bad Wolf expansion was initially available through the Kickstarter, and was available individually, as well as part of the "Monster Bundle III".

The Big Bad Wolf expansion is not a Kickstarter Exclusive.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Three Little Pigs

Name: Lobotomy: The Tire Expansion
Description:
This expansion introduces the The Tire monster, and includes a miniature and rules.

The Tire expansion was initially available through the Kickstarter, and was only available individually.

The Tire expansion is not a Kickstarter Exclusive.

Name: Lobotomy: B.A. Dolly
Description:
This expansion introduces the B.A. Dolly character, and includes a miniature, four skill cards, and ten memory cards.

The B.A. Dolly character was a Kickstarter Exclusive.
